editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE ROYALL, AND THE ROYALLIST'S Plea.

Shewing, That the Kings Maje≈øty hath the chiefe Power In this Realme, and other his Dominions, [1 Pet. 2.13.] And to him the chiefe Government of all E≈øtates of this Realme, whether they be Civill or Eccle≈øia≈øticall, in all Cau≈øes doth appertaine. Artic. 27. of Religion concerning Magi≈øt.

Wee Confe≈ø≈øe and Acknowledge, Empires, Kingdomes, Dominions and Cities, to be di≈øtincted and ordayned by God, for the Manife≈øtation of his owne Glory, and for the ≈øingular Profit and Commodity of Mankinde, [Prov. 24.21.22.] So that who≈øoever goeth about to take away, or confound the whole State of Civill Policies, now long e≈øtabli≈øhed; Wee affirme the ≈øame men, not only to bee Enemies to Mankinde, but al≈øo wickedly to fight again≈øt Gods expre≈ø≈øe Will. Confe≈ø≈ø. of the church of Scotland, concerning the Civill Magi≈øtrate.

p.hi: And the fir≈øt thing Wee Covenant is, to defend and maintayne the Doctrine of that Church.

div.p: Ano. Domi. 1647.

BEFORE I treate of the differences betweene the King and the Parliament,Of the con≈øtitution of the kingdome of England. and ≈øet forth the Grounds and Intents of the Warre on both ≈øides (either Party charging the Other, with a De≈øigne to overthrowe the e≈øtabli≈øhed Government of the Kingdome) I ≈øhall promi≈øe ≈øomething concerning the Con≈øtitution of the Kingdome, and Parliament of England.

And, whereas there are three kindes of Governement,Three kinds of Government. The fir≈øt Monarchicall, by One; The ≈øecond Ari≈øtocraticall, by the Nobles; The third Democraticall, England a Monarchy, it con≈øi≈øts of a head and a ≈øubject body. by the People. The Government of England is of the fir≈øt ≈øort, Monarchicall. And the Monarch is the Head, And (with us) tho Barons and the People, are the Subject-Body of the Kingdome.

The King governs the Church by Archbi≈øhops & Bi≈øhops, And the Civill State by Temporall Officers: And to enable him for that his Admini≈øtration and Government,Sundry Politicall Powers in the Monarch for governing the kingdome in it ≈øelfe, & in order to other Princes and States. the King is inve≈øted with ≈øundry politicall Powers as of Treaties of Warre and Peace, of making Peeres, of choo≈øing Officers and Councellors for State, Judges for Lawe, Commanders for Forts and Ca≈øtles, giving Commi≈ø≈øions for ray≈øing Men, to mako warre abroad, or to provide again≈øt inva≈øions or in≈øurrections at home, benefit of Confi≈øcations power of Pardoning, and others of the like kind:The nece≈ø≈øity of the≈øe Powers in the King. And by this Power and Authority he drawes a re≈øpect and relation from the Nobles, and feare and reverence from the People, and thereby prevents divi≈øion
faction in the one; tumults, violence and Licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe in the other, and ≈øo pre≈øerves Peace and unity among≈øt us: as al≈øo by the Authority & Power afore≈øaid, The King is enabled to di≈øcharge his Office & Oath, to pre≈øerve the Lawes of the Land in their force, and the Subjects in their Properties and Liberties.

The Parliament con≈øi≈øts of a Head and ‚Ä¢
≈øubject Body.And as the Kingdome, ≈øo the Parliament of England, is con≈øtituted of a Head, and a Subject-Body; The King being the Head, and the two Hou≈øes the Subject-Body of the Parliament.

q.l: The King calls the Parliament and di≈ø≈øolves it.
He calls each Baron by a peculiar Writ.

div.p: He ≈øends forth Writs into the ≈øeverall Counties, & into the Cities & Boroughs for electing Knights,A Proxy acts for another by a≈ø≈øenting & di≈ø≈øenting for him but hath no ≈øuperiority or authority over him for whom he acts. Citizens & Burge≈ø≈øes to ≈øerve for them: and the people meete & choo≈øe accordingly, & ≈øend up the per≈øons ≈øo cho≈øen, as their Proxies, to ≈øit and Vote for them by way of a≈ø≈øent and di≈ø≈øent, upon all occa≈øions in Parliament: and ≈øo the King and the whole Kingdome (by their Repre≈øentatives) convene in Parliament.

As the Barons ≈øweare fealty to the King at their Creation ≈øo the Law requires the Members of the Hou≈øe of Commons to take the oath of Allegiance & Supremacy,The Lords and Commons ≈øweare fealty & allegiance to the King. before they are admitted to ≈øit there.

The principall Power and work of the Parliament is in Law making: and our Lawes are made thus, Bills are framed & agreed on by the Lords & Commons and afterward pre≈øented to the King,How our lawes are made. and by the Royall a≈ø≈øent they become Lawes. And this is that which the King ≈øweares to at his Coronation, and it is well expre≈ø≈øed in the forme at the Coronation of Edward the ≈øixt in the≈øe following words.The Oath at king Edwards Coronation. Doe you grant to make no new Lawes, but ≈øuch as ≈øhall be to the honor of God, and to the good of the Common-wealth, and that the ≈øame ≈øhall bee made by the con≈øent of your People, as hath beene accu≈øtomed?

Liberty of vote an e≈ø≈øentiall priviledge of Parliament.And in pa≈ø≈øing of Bills, The King & the Lords and the Commons are to Vote freely, and this liberty of Vote, is the mo≈øt e≈ø≈øentiall priviledge of Parliament, yea, The King and
the Lords and Commons,Of their Negative Votes. have every of them their Negative Vote in this Ca≈øe, thereby to pre≈øerve them≈øelves and theis Rights and Priviledges one again≈øt another: And ≈øo to keepe the Con≈øtitution of the kingdome inviolate.

And it is a peculiar Priviledge of the hou≈øe of Commons, to make the fir≈øt Propo≈øitions for the Levies of Money,The priviledge of the Hou≈øe of Commons. which is the Sinews both of Peace and Warre. Al≈øo that hou≈øe takes notice of the violating of our Liberties, and impeacheth tho≈øe that have oppre≈ø≈øed and grieved the Subject.
And the Lords proceede again≈øt them in a judiciary way,The Judiciary power of the hou≈øe of Lords to remedy mi≈øgovernment. & puni≈øh them.

But in this Ca≈øe the Law ≈øayes, The King can doe no wrong. And if any thing be done ami≈ø≈øe in matter of State, the Councell: If in matter of Ju≈øtice,The King can doe no wrong. the Judges mu≈øt an≈øwer for it, as them≈øelves have declared, May 19. Husbands Collect. pag. 199.
The Hou≈øe of Lords hath al≈øo a judiary Power upon Writts of Error brought again≈øt Judgements in inferiour Courts.
Al≈øo, eyther Hou≈øe hath Power over their own Members: But over the Subject at large and in Generall (without the Kings Concurrence) neither hou≈øe hath Power, nor both of them joyned together.

Much le≈ø≈øe have they power over their Soveraigne Lord the King,They ought to ≈øupport the king and the Crowne, & not to invade and null them. who hath no Superior under God (25, Hen. 8.) & much le≈ø≈øe over the imperiall Crowne (which hath beene free at all times, and in no earthly Subjection, but immediatly to God in all things touching the Regality of the ≈øaid Crown 16. R. 2.5.) And which was never invaded by any Parliawent before, and there is nothing of Power extraordinary in the pre≈øent Parliament, but of cantinuance only, being not to be di≈ø≈øolved but with the con≈øent of both hou≈øes of Parlament.The privileges of the Members of Parliament.

La≈øtly, touching the priviledg of the Members of Parliament them≈øelves (in their Petition to his Maje≈øty at the beginning of his Reigne, in the Ca≈øe of the Earle of Arundell) have declared thus. Wee finde it an undoubted Right and con≈øtant priviledge of Parliament. That no Member of Parliament,
≈øitting in the Parliament, or within the u≈øuall times of the priviledge of Parliament, is to bee re≈øtrayned or imme≈øoned, without Sentence of the Hou≈øe, unle≈ø≈øe it bee for high-Trea≈øon, Felony, or for refu≈øing to give Surety for the Peace.

And ≈øo in Q. Elizabeths time, when Wentworth made tho≈øe motions that were, Wentworths Ca≈øe. but ≈øuppo≈øed dangerous to the Queens E≈øtate; Hee was impri≈øoned in the Tower, notwith≈øtanding the priviledge of the Hou≈øe, & there dyed.

Thus whereas there is in every of the three kindes of Government ≈øome good (as ∆≤nity in Monarchy; The equall & happy con≈øtitution of England. Coun≈øell in Ari≈øtocracy; Liberty in Democracy) and ≈øome evills, (as Tyranny in Monarchy; Divi≈øion & Faction in Ari≈øtocracy; Tumults, Violence and Licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe in Democracy.) By the Con≈øtitution of the Kingdome we have the good of all the≈øe without the evill of any. And hence, for ≈øo many hundred yeeres hath the Engli≈øh Nation beene famous & happy to admiration and envy: Pro. 24 21.22 Even from this Ancient, Equall, Happy,At pre≈øent the Lords & Commons ≈øhake off the yoke of ≈øubjection, and affect the chiefe Power & Government; ‚Ä¢ or doe they Act as our fellow ≈øubjects & Proxi ‚Ä¢ s, but as our Lords and Ma≈øters, nor doe they ≈øtudy Liberty with us, and for us, but Soveraignty over us. Well-poized, & never enough commended Con≈øtitution of this Kingdome: From which receding, all the≈øe Politicall Evills have overtaken us. Even Tyranny and Oppre≈ø≈øion, Divi≈øion and Faction, Tumults, Violence and Licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe: And what will or can be the end of this but Anarchy, Confu≈øion and utter De≈øtruction of the King, of the Parliament, of the Kingdome, of the N ‚Ä¢ tion?

p.q: Oh that they were wi≈øe, that they under≈øtood, that they would con≈øider their latter end. Deut.32.29.

div.head: THE ROYALL, and ROYALLIST'S PLEA.
div.p: THAT the chiefe Promoter of the pre≈øent war had a de≈øigne again≈øt his Maje≈øty and again≈øt Monarchy, is now manife≈øt to all the World,The Vote for ≈øending the king to Warwick Ca≈øtle. by the la≈øt vote for ≈øending the King to Warwick Ca≈øtle; and by Mr. Prideux his ≈øpeech in October la≈øt, for,Mr. Prideux his ≈øpeech, for abandoning Monarchy. abandoning Monarchy (now they have gotten the power of the Sword) and for ≈øetling the government of the Kingdome in the two Hou≈øes of Parliament.
But our Plea is grounded upon former Evidences,The ground of this Plea. from the very ≈øummoning of this Parliament, unto the taking up of armes.

For how did they ≈øtickle in the Counties and Burroughs,They Stickle about Elections. for ≈øuch to be elected into the hou≈øe of Commons as were of their opinions and inclinations? And no ≈øooner did they meete and ≈øit in Parliament, but they ratified and damned Elections at plea≈øure, in Order to their De≈øigne.
A Bill again≈øt Bi≈øhops, & the Militia.
Seditious Lecturers and Pampleters.
The Prote≈øtation prote≈øted, and To thy Tents Oh I≈ørael.
Tumults.

The Members thus prepared: They bring in two Bills The one to take away Bi≈øhops, Roote and Branch, The other to take the Militia, by Sea and Land from the King; the later beeing preferred by Sr. Arthur Ha≈ølerigg.

And fayling in this way, thee ≈øend forth factious and ≈øeditious Lecturers, which inveigh again≈øt the pre≈øent Government of Church and State, and they Licen≈øe Pamphlets, that deprave the Government of the Kingdom.

The people thus prepared, They ray≈øe tumults in London,
to force and compell the Parliament to joyne with them,Tho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ accu≈øed Memb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ protected in the pro≈øecution of their De≈øigne; and his Maje≈øty charging them with high Trea≈øon for the≈øe attempts again≈øt him≈øelfe and again≈øt the Parliament: They get them≈øelves protected under the pretended priviledge of Parliament: from verball they fall to reall-Trea≈øons; and they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them≈øelves of the Forts and Ca≈øtles, after that his Maje≈øty had promi≈øed for their ≈øecurity, that they ≈øhould be only in ≈øuch hands as they ≈øhould have cau≈øe to confide in. Jan. 27.

The Forts and Ca≈øtles, & the Militia‚ñ™ with the Navy Royall taken from his Maje≈øty.And they di≈øpo≈øe and execute the Militia of the Kingdome, altogether excluding his Maje≈øty, after that for their farther ≈øecurity, he had accepted of the Lords Lieutenants in the ≈øeverall Counties recommended by them Feb. 28. And after he had condi≈øcended touching the Militia of the Corporations April. 8.

What rea≈øon they pretended for the MilitiaIn the la≈øt places they ≈øeize on the Navy-Royall. And (in their votes of March 15.) she rea≈øon pretended for the Militia, was to defend the kingdome again≈øt Enemies from abroad (when we had none) and again≈øt the Papi≈øts at home (when they were naked and without Armes) and again≈øt a di≈øcontented party among≈øt us (i.e.) again≈øt the King and his party, whom they had di≈øcontented and highly provoked by their late proceedings.

See the opinion of the judges in the Ca≈øe of the E. of E≈ø≈øex.And as their ≈øeizing their Forts and Ca≈øtles, &c. was needle≈ø≈øe in the two former re≈øpects, ≈øo in the later was it Rebellious, being not for the publique, but for their private ≈øecurity and advantage: not to defend the Kingdome again≈øt danger, but to protect them≈øelves again≈øt ju≈øtice: not to put us into a po≈øture of defence again≈øt a common Enemy, but to put them≈øelves into a po≈øture of power and ≈øtrength again≈øt his Maje≈øty, thereby at once enabling them≈øelves to force him and di≈øable him to re≈øi≈øt them in the pro≈øecution of their de≈øigne again≈øt him.
And no ≈øooner had they got the full ≈øtrength of the kingdome, but they actually and profe≈ø≈øedly ≈øet them≈øelves again≈øt his Maje≈øty.
Sir John Hotham keepes him out of Hull Aprill. 23. Sr. John Hotham. And the two Hou≈øes ju≈øtifie his Trayterous Act Aprill 28.

Not long after Mr. Martin ≈øayes openly in the hou≈øe of Commons, and unreproved.Mr. Martin. That the Kings Office is forfeitable. And that the happine≈ø≈øe of this Kingdome,They ≈øtrike at Monarchy, as at Epi≈øcopacy, root & branch. did not depend upon his Maje≈øty, or any of the Royall branches of that Roote.

And Sy ‚Ä¢
Henry Ludlow. That he was not worthy to be King of England,
Sr. Henry Ludlow.
Both Hou≈øes tacitly imply the depo≈øing of the King.
They make attempts upon the Imperiall Crowne.
The Kings Negative vote. The 19 Propo≈øitions. which doubtle≈ø≈øe was the ≈øence of the Parliament. For May 26. both hou≈øes declare. That they ≈øhould not want mode≈øty if they follow'd the highe≈øt Precedents of other Parliaments.
The Crowne it ≈øelfe cannot e≈øcape them, nay they ayme at that ultimately:
For in the ≈øame Declaration they deny the kings negative Vote in Parliament.
And to deprive the King and the Crown of their power, not only in Law-making, but al≈øo in Governing, They offer to his Maje≈øty 19 Propo≈øitions, de≈øtructive of Regality and Monarchy Iune 2.

And they enforce them as ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to the publique ≈øafety; whereas to the Kingdomes ≈øecurity, The Forts, and Ca≈øtles, and the Militia, and the Navy, alone are ≈øufficient, in ca≈øe of danger: and ≈øo the particulars are propo≈øed and impo≈øed on his Maje≈øty, only by way of de≈øigne, to undermine King≈øhip and Monarchy. And his Maje≈øties former condi≈øcentions touching the Forts and Ca≈øtles, and the Militia, and the Navy,Note. being more then ≈øufficient again≈øt their pretended dangers, at pre≈øent, they al≈øo are demanded, not for nece≈ø≈øity, but meerly of de≈øigne and policie:They claime an ab≈øolute power over the Subject, in Order to their Cau≈øe, and to the pre≈øent Warre. And they take up Armes in pro≈øecution of the≈øe Propo≈øitions and demands, Iune 10. After they had in the forecited-Declaration of May 26. claimed a power over the people of the Land, to di≈øpo≈øe of their per≈øons and e≈øtates, in Order to their Cau≈øe, and to compell them to ≈øerve in the pre≈øent Warre.

The whol Series of Occurrents di≈øcover their De≈øigne.Thus the entire Series of Occurrents (from their Summons to their Armes) plainly di≈øcovers the malice of their hearts, and the Reality of their De≈øigne, again≈øt the King, and again≈øt the Crowne.

The ≈øeverall particulars ≈øhew how they have moved from time to time.And the ≈øeverall particulars ≈øhew cleerly how they have moved from time to time; fir≈øt in a Parliamentary way by Bill, then by Pamphlets, in a ≈øeditious way; afterwards in a Tumultuary way, again≈øt the Parliament; Next, under the pretended priviledg of Parliament, again≈øt the king; Then by u≈øurping the ≈øtrength of the Kingdome, and with in≈øolency again≈øt his Maje≈øty, and not without attempts upon the Crowne it ≈øelfe; And la≈øtly (other meanes being ineffectuall) by force of Armes,Why they ray≈øed their Arms and continue them, & when they will lay them downe. ray≈øed at fir≈øt to maintain and make good what≈øoever they had preferred, publi≈øhed acted, u≈øurped, ≈øpoken, declared, propo≈øed; and to drive on their De≈øigne again≈øt the King, and to alter the Government of the Kingdome, and to this day continued to perfect that alteration (begun in part already) and not to bee laid downe, till it be compleated and ≈øetled, to the utter overthrow of Monarchy; and con≈øequently to the Ruine and de≈øtruction of his Maje≈øty and his Po≈øterity, who are the only Rub in their way, and to be nece≈ø≈øarily removed, before their dominion can be e≈øtabli≈øhed.

I ≈øhall omit all other Particulars before rehear≈øed (leaveing them to the further con≈øideration of every private man) and in≈øi≈øt only on the Propo≈øitions,Why the other particulars were omitted, and the Propo≈øitions only in≈øi≈øted on. which are the very drift of all the former proceedings, and a lively Portraiture of the whole Plot, and the rea≈øon of the fir≈øt Armes, and the con≈øtant Argument of their Treaties, and con≈øequently the ground and end of the Warre.

div.head: The true ≈øtate of the Warre, on the Kings ≈øide and on the Parliaments.
div.p: THE Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament alleage, That there was a De≈øigne by Papi≈øts,The Allegation of the Lords and Commons for taking up Armes. and by an ill-aff ‚Ä¢ cted Party, to overthrowe our Religion, Lawes and Liberties, and to introduce Popery and Tyranny, and that they tooke up Armes to defend our Religion, L ‚Ä¢ wes and Liberties.

The King alleageth, That there was a De≈øigne by a factious, ≈øeditious, anti-Monarchicall Party,The Kings Allegation for his taking up of Armes. to overthrowe the e≈øtabli≈øhed government of Church and State, and to ≈øettle the chiefe Power and Government in the two Hou≈øes of Parliament: And that upon their Allegation afore≈øaid, and in Order to their De≈øigne afore≈øaid, the two Hou≈øes have claimed and exerci≈øed a Soveraigne Power over the Lawes of the Land, and an Arbitrary and Tyrannicall Power over our per≈øons and E≈øtates, and have levyed warre, and compelled us to ≈øerve in the warre, as was pretended to keepe out Tyranny and Popery, and ≈øo to carry on their De≈øigne again≈øt Regallity and Monarchy. And his Maje≈øty tooke up Armes, as he alleageth, to maintaine the ancient Government of the Kingdome, and our e≈øtabli≈øhed Religion, Lawes and Liberty.

Now the true cau≈øe of taking up and continuing of Armes on each ≈øide,The true Cau≈øe of the war, on both ≈øides. is be≈øt knowne by their Propo≈øitions offered before, and treated on ≈øince the warre,

div.head: The Parliaments Propo≈øitions.The Parliaments Propo≈øitions.
div.p: THAT a Bill be pa≈ø≈øed for the utter aboli≈øhing and taking away Arch-Bi≈øhops, &c.For aboli≈øhing Bi≈øhops.

For nominating the Officers of State, and the Judges in England.That the Lord high Steward of England, Lord high Con≈øtable, Lord Chancellor or Keeper of the Great-Seale, Lord Trea≈øurer, Lord Privy Seale, Earle Mar≈øhall, Lord Admiral, Warden of the Cinque-ports, Chancelour of the Exchequor, Ma≈øter of the Wards, Secretaries of State, two Cheife Ju≈øtices, and the Cheife Baron, be nominated by both Hou≈øes of Parliament.

The like for Ireland.The like for the kingdome of Ireland, as touching the Deputy, or cheife Governour, or other Governour there, and the Pre≈øidents of the ≈øeverall Provinces, the Chancellor or L. Keeper, L. Trea≈øurer, &c.

The Educating of the Kings children.That he or they unto whom the Government of the kings children ≈øhall be committed, ≈øhall bee approved of by both Hou≈øes of Parliament, and their ≈øervants likewi≈øe.

For marrying them.That no marriage ≈øhall be concluded, or treated, for any of the Kings children, with any forraigne Prince, or other per≈øon what≈øoever, abroad or at home, without con≈øent of the Parliament.

For the MilitiaThat the Militia be ≈øetled, and the Subjects of the Kingdomes of England and Ireland, be appointed to be Armed Trayned and Di≈øciplined, in ≈øuch manner as both Hou≈øes of Parliament ≈øhall thinke fit.
For the Admiralty and Navy.That the Admiralty and force at Sea, and power of ray≈øing Money for the maintenance of tho≈øe Forces, and of the Navy, bee ≈øetled in the two Hou≈øes of Parliament.
For the Forts and Ca≈øtles.That the Forts and Ca≈øtles of the Kingdome ≈øhall be put under the Command and Cu≈øtody of ≈øuch Per≈øons as ≈øhall be approved of by both Hou≈øes of Parliament.
For the votes of Peeres to be made hereafterThat no Peere made hereafter, ≈øhall ≈øit or vote in Parliament, unle≈ø≈øe they bee admitted thereto by both Hou≈øes of Parliament.

For concluding of Peace & warThat the Concluding of Peace and Warre with forraigne Princes and States bee with the advice of the Parliaments of both Kingdomes.A quere upon the Parliaments Propo≈øitions.

Now the Que≈øtion is, Whether (the≈øe Propo≈øitions
con≈øidered) The two Hou≈øes of Parliament doe truely take up Armes and continue them, for the defence of our Religion, Lawes and Liberties, again≈øt Popery and Tyranny, as is alleaged by them; or not rather for the overthrowe of the e≈øtabli≈øhed Government of Church and State, and of Reg ‚Ä¢ llity and Monarchy; and for ≈øetling the cheife Power in the two Hou≈øes of Parliament as is alleaged by his Maje≈øty.

There are I know other Propo≈øitions concerning Delinquents, but ≈øubordinate to tho≈øe that tend to the alteration of Government.Their Propo≈øitions concerning Delinquents. Their Delinquents being only ≈øuch as are enemies to their Cau≈øe, and have from time to time oppo≈øed their proceedings again≈øt the King, and again≈øt the pre≈øent Government, as appeares plainly by their Ordinances concerning Delinquents, and by the Catalogue of Delinquents delivered in at the Treaties, and in≈øerted among≈øt their Propo≈øitions: And they pro≈øecute them not in a Judiciary and Parliamentary way, as Legall offenders; but in a Military and Ho≈øtile way, as an adver≈øe party, Oppo≈øite to them and their De≈øigne.

Now, whether the≈øe Gentlemen be Delinquents or no, ≈øhall be ≈øhewed afterward, upon ≈øtating the warre on both ≈øides; Delinquency being not where the Cau≈øe is ju≈øt, and the warre lawfull; but where the Cau≈øe and the warre are unju≈øt, and unlawfull, that is the Delinquent Party.

Their Propo≈øitions concerning Papi≈øts I have omitted,Their Propo≈øitions concerning Papi≈øts. becau≈øe the King a≈ø≈øented to them. (And how did they take up Armes for the defence of our Religion again≈øt Popery?)

Concerning our Liberties they propo≈øed nothing,No Propo≈øition concerning our Liberty. all the Grievances ≈øet forth by the Lords in their Petition pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty at Yorke, being remedied by ≈øeverall Acts at the beginning of this Parliament. And how then did they take up Armes for defence of our Liberties, again≈øt Tyranny?

Al≈øo there is nothing propo≈øed concerning our Lawes;
their whole proceedings being again≈øt Lawe;An ob≈øervation of the Kings Commi≈ø≈øioners at Uxbridge. eyther again≈øt the twenty fift of Edward the third, in point of Trea≈øon again≈øt the King; Or again≈øt Magna Charta, and the Petition of Right, in point of oppre≈ø≈øion of the Subject. As al≈øo by their Orders, The two Hou≈øes and each Hou≈øe, and their Committees ≈øtop the proceedings of the Courts of Ju≈øtice, in Suites of Lawe, betweene Man and Man.

And ≈øo the Kings Commi≈ø≈øioners at the Treaty at Uxbridge ob≈øerved, That after a warre of neere foure yeeres for which the defence of the Prote≈øtant Religion, The liberty and property of the Subject, and the priviledges of Parliament, were made the cau≈øe and ground, in a Treaty of twenty daies, nor indeede in the whole Propo≈øitions, upon which the Treaty ≈øhould be, there hath been nothing offered to be Treated concerning the breach of any Law, or of the Liberty and Property of the Subject, or Priviledge of Parliament; but only Propo≈øitions for the altering of a Government, e≈øtabli≈øhed by Lawe, and for the makeing new Lawes, by which all the old are, or may bee cancelled.

div.head: The Kings Propo≈øitions.
div.p: For his Revenues Magazine &c.THAT his Maje≈øties owne Revenue, Magazine, Townes, Forts, and Ships, which have beene taken or kept from him, by force, bee forthwith re≈øtored unto him.

For maintayning the Lawes of the Land, & the kings Legall Power & Right.
For the Liberty of the Subject again≈øt illegall Power. That what≈øoever hath beene done or publi≈øhed contrary to the knowne Lawes of the Land, or derogatorie to his Maje≈øties Legall and known Power and Right; be renounced and recalled, that no ≈øeede may remaine, for the like to ≈øpring out for the future.

That what≈øoever illegall power hath beene claimed and exerci≈øed over his Subjects; as impri≈øoning their per≈øons
without Lawe; ≈øtopping their Habeas corpus, and impo≈øing upon their e≈øtates without Act of Parliament, eyther by both or eyther Hou≈øe, or any Committee of both or eyther, or by any per≈øons appointed by any of them, bee di≈øclaymed, and all ≈øuch per≈øons ≈øo Committed forthwith di≈øcharged.

That as his Maje≈øty will readily con≈øent, having done ≈øo heretofore, to the execution of all Lawes already made,Again≈øt Popery. and to any good Act to be made for the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of Popery, and for the firme ≈øetling the Prote≈øtant Religion by Lawe e≈øtabli≈øhed; So he de≈øires that a good Bill may bee framed, for the better preferring of the booke of Common-Prayer, from the ≈øcorne and violence of Browni≈øts,For the booke of Common Prayer. Anabapti≈øts and other Sectaries, with ≈øuch clau≈øes for the ea≈øe of tender Con≈øciences, as his Maje≈øty hath formerly offered.

That all ≈øuch per≈øons as upon the Treaty ≈øhall be excepted out of rhe generall Pardon, ≈øhall be tryed per Pares, For the tryall of Delinquents according to the u≈øuall cour≈øe and known Lawes of the Land, and that it be left to that, eyther to acquit or condemne them.

Now the que≈øtion is,A quere upon the Kings Propo≈øitions. whether (the≈øe Propo≈øitions con≈øidered) the King doth truely take up Armes, and continue them, to maintaine our Religion, Lawes, and Liberties; again≈øt Popery and Tyranny, as is aleaged by his Maje≈øty, or to overthrow them, as is alleaged by the two hou≈øes of Parliament.

But the Lords and Commons pleade for them≈øelves finally. That they tooke up Armes, and continue them,The final Plea of the Lords & Commons retorted: to pro≈øecute their Propo≈øitions, only in Order to the defence of our Religion, Lawes and Liberties. Or rather they tooke Armes, and continue them, for the defence of our Religion, Lawes and Liberties only, in, Grder to the pro≈øecution of the≈øe their Propo≈øitions, and of their De≈øigne; Seeing they will not acquie≈øce in his Maje≈øties, which are directly and apparently for the e≈øtabli≈øhing of our Religion, Lawes and
Liberties, again≈øt Popery and Tyranny, but offer and pre≈ø≈øe their owne Propo≈øitions, to the overthrow of our Religion by Lawe e≈øtabli≈øhed, and of the e≈øtabli≈øhed Government of Church and State.

Be≈øides, before Armes were taken up, his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to recede from his Right touching Forts,The King recedes from his Right, & from the ‚Ä¢ rigour of his Propo≈øitions. and Ca≈øtles, and the Militia; and he condi≈øcended to them in divers other particulars, touching their nineteene Propo≈øititions; thereby (if po≈ø≈øible) to have prevented the Warre among≈øt us. And after that Armes were taken up, and the kingdome embroyled in Warre (to prevent the further mi≈øchiefes thereof) his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to recede from the rigour of his Propo≈øitions; and at the Treaty at Uxbridge, by his Commi≈ø≈øioners, he would have complyed in ≈øeverall particulars touching the Bi≈øhops and the Deans and Chapters: and he would have tru≈øted them with the Militia for two yeeres, and afterward by a Me≈ø≈øage from Oxford, he graciou≈øly conde≈øcended:
1. That all who are Prote≈øtants ≈øhould have the free exerci≈øe of Religion according to their owne way.
The Kings Me≈ø≈øage from Ozford.2. That the two hou≈øes of Parliament ≈øhould have the Militia for 7 yeeres.
3 That they, pro hac vice, ≈øhould chu≈øe the Lord Admirall, and Officers of State, and the Judges.
4. That the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of Ireland ≈øhould be referred wholly to them.
5. That hee would joyne with them in an Act for the payment of the publique debts.
6. That he would pa≈ø≈øe a Generall Act of Oblivion.

I ≈øay the King was plea≈øed, in favour to the Parliament, and the Subject, to recede from the Rigour of his Propo≈øitions: But the two Hou≈øes would never abate one jot of their Propo≈øitions and demands,They will not recede one jot from the rigor of their Propo≈øitions. in favour of his Maje≈øty or Monarchy; but rather have ≈øcrued them up from time to time, and heightned them again≈øt both. Nor will they now be ≈øatisfied with the e≈øtabli≈øhing of our Religion, Lawes,
and Liberties, unle≈ø≈øe it bee by way of their Propo≈øitions thus heightned: And ≈øo they encroach upon the Crowne daily, more and more, untill at length they inve≈øt them≈øelves in the full Power and Rights of the King and of the Crowne.

And at fir≈øt they pretended the defence of our Religion,The defence of our Religion, L ‚Ä¢ wes and Liberties pretended, and why Lawes and Liberties, in policy only (that they might more effectually prevaile with the people, and more colourably ≈øeize the Militia, and ray≈øe an Army) for by their Armes, they doe not only, not defend our Religion,P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ te≈øtatio contraria facto. Lawes and Liberties, but (taking upon them Soveraigne authority over our Lawes, and an Arbitrary Power over our Per≈øons and E≈øtates) they aboli≈øh our Religion, by Lawe e≈øtabli≈øhed,By their Arms they doe not only not defend our Religion, Lawes & Liberties, but invade and violate them. in Doctrine, Wor≈øhip, Di≈øcipline and Government (to comply with the Independents, Browni≈øts, Anabapti≈øts, and other Sectaries, to make them of their party to carry on their De≈øigne again≈øt Munarchy) And they trample under foote our Lawes, and invade and violate our Liberties, in pro≈øecution of their De≈øigne, again≈øt his Maje≈øty, and in him, again≈øt Monarchy: O ‚Ä¢ dayning, contrary to the Petition of Right, That we beare Armes, billet Souldiers, pay Monies and take Oathes, not impo≈øed by Act of Parliament; And upon our refu≈øall, Seque≈øtring and Impri≈øoning us, without more adoe; and proceeding al≈øo again≈øt ≈øome by Martiall-Lawe, and Condemning and Executing them: Whereas by Magna Charta, no man ≈øhould bee di≈ø≈øeized of his E≈øtate, nor Impri≈øoned, nor ≈øuffer, but upon tryall by his Peeres.

But who would haue beleeved, that our Religion, Liberty and Lawes, which for ≈øo long a time have endured Oppo≈øition and A≈ø≈øaults from forreigne Power, envying our happine≈ø≈øe, would have beene Oppo≈øed, Oppre≈ø≈øed, and Trod under foote by the Crafts and Cruelties of our owne Natives and Country-men? As is declared by both Kingdomes joyned in Armes for pur≈øuance of the Covenant Janu. 30. 1643.

This a mo≈øt dangerous precedent. The true ≈øtate of the war, on the Parliaments ≈øide.
There is not Law warranting the Lords & Commons to take up Armes.
Rom. 3.8.
Their pre≈øent War is, Fir≈øt unnece≈ø≈øary as pretending the defence of our Religion, laws and Liberties again≈øt Popery and Tyranny. Secondly, unju≈øt as contending for the King & crown. Thirdly, wicked, as intending the overthrowe of the Con≈øtitution & Government of the kingdom and intimating the de≈øtruction of the King & his Po≈øteritie in order thereto.
No priviledge in Ca≈øe of trea≈øon.
Having got the power of the Sword, they may rule and over-rule the king & people, & invade his other Rights and their Liberties at plea≈øure. And Oh! the un≈øtable and mi≈øerable Condition of the Engli≈øh Nation, if the two Hou≈øes of Parliament or a prevayling factious Party there, may at plea≈øure alter our E≈øtabli≈øhed Religion, Lawes, Liberty, Property and Government.

And ≈øo (the Premi≈øes con≈øidered) the true ≈øtate of the Que≈øtion concerning the Warre on the Parliaments ≈øide, is clearely this. Not whether the Lords and Commons may ≈øeize and deteine his Maje≈øties Forts and Ships; Nor whether they may ≈øettle and di≈øpo≈øe the Militia and the Navy, and ray≈øe an Army for the defence of our Religion, Lawes and Liberties (though to doe any of the≈øe without the Royall Authority, upon any Pretences, or to any Intentions what≈øoever, whether to expul≈øe Strangers, to remove Coun≈øellors, or again≈øt any Statute, &c. bee to levy warre again≈øt the King? becau≈øe they take upon them Royall authority, which is again≈øt the King, Cooke 3. part In≈øtitut. Cap. de high-Trea≈øon. And I know no difference between the Lords and Commons in Parliament (in this Ca≈øe) and others out of Parliament, all being in the condition of ≈øubjects to his Maje≈øty, and there being no priviledge of Parliament in Ca≈øe of Trea≈øon: But whether they may put them≈øelves into the ≈øtrength of the Kingdome, and ray≈øe forces, and employ them to the intents and purpo≈øes expre≈ø≈øed in their Propo≈øitions, viz. For taking from the King and from the Crowne the Government of the Church by Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, &c. and the Government of the State likewi≈øe, while≈øt they would nominate the great Officers and the Judges, and would di≈øpo≈øe the Militia, and the Navy, and the Forts and Ca≈øtles, &c. And for ≈øetling the chiefe power and Government both of Church and State, at pre≈øent in them≈øelves, and in the two Hou≈øes of Parliament hereafter; yea for Subjects (and ≈øuch are the Lords and Commons in the pre≈øent Parliament a≈ø≈øembled) to put them≈øelves into ≈øuch a ≈øtrength as the king ≈øhall not be able to re≈øi≈øt them, and to force and compell
the King to governe otherwi≈øe then according to his owne Royall authority and direction is manife≈øt Rebellion,It is manife≈øt Rebellion. according to the opinion of the Judges deliveeed at the arraignement of the Earle of E≈ø≈øex.
How much more in our pre≈øent Ca≈øe,Their Rebellion aggravated. when they would take away the power and governement from the King and Crowne?

Againe, The premi≈øes con≈øidered,The true ≈øtate of the warre on the Kings ≈øide. The warre on the Kings ≈øide is vindicatory and defen≈øorie, in re≈øpect of the Kings power and righ ‚Ä¢ , and of the Lawes of the Land, and of the Liberty and property of the Subject. The true ≈øtate of the que≈øtion concerning the Warre on the Kings ≈øide is cleerly this. Not whether he may rai≈øe an Army again≈øt the Parliament (though if he ≈øhould, I know no warrant for re≈øi≈øting him,) But whether the King may not rai≈øe an Army, and fight again≈øt the Parliament, for the rea≈øons expre≈ø≈øed in his Propo≈øitions. viz.
For the recovery of his Revenue, Forts and Ca≈øtles &c.
For vindicating the Lawes of the Land, and his Legall power and Rights &c.
For Redeeming the Subject from illegall-power, and from manifold oppre≈ø≈øion.
For pre≈øerving the e≈øtabli≈øhed Liturgy &c.

For bringing Delinquents to a Legall-Tryall. The Lords and Commons in Parliament, as well as other his Subjects, being lyable to his Maje≈øties di≈øplea≈øure, when≈øoever they keepe not them≈øelves within the circle of the Law, and Cu≈øtome of Parliament. Cooke lib. of Juri≈ødiction of Courts. Note. Cap. High Court of Parliament. And them≈øelves have declared, That all forcible practi≈øes,Malignancie, Delinquencie, and Covenanting, &c. The true ≈øtate of the que≈øtion concerning the depo≈øing of the King. much more ≈øuch Rebellious proceedings again≈øt the King, are incon≈øi≈øtent with the Nature of the Councell, being the Body whereof his Maje≈øty is the Head. Husb. Collect. of Remon≈øt. pag. 100. And from tho≈øe expre≈ø≈øe ends in the Propo≈øitions on both ≈øides mu≈øt we judge, as of the warre, ≈øo of the incidents thereto; Malignancy, Delinquency, Covenanting, &c. And of the con≈øequents thereof, the blood-≈øhed and ≈øpoyle in England, and the lo≈ø≈øe of Ireland, and the blood and trea≈øon to be expended in the recovery thereof, and the depo≈øing of the
king (though no prote≈øtant Parliament ever did ≈øo, and Prote≈øtants generally abominate the doctrine of Depo≈øing of Kings. Dan. 2.2 ‚Ä¢ . Dan. 4.17.25.32. Rom. 13.14 4. The Ob≈øervator him≈øelfe ≈øayes, That never was any King depo≈øed in a free Parliament:) But whether the Parliament may depo≈øe the King, becau≈øe he hath taken up Armes and ≈øought again≈øt them.
For recovery of his Revenues, &c.
For vindicating the Lawes of the Land, and his Legall power and Rights.
For Redeeming the Subject from illegall power, &c.

And becau≈øe he will not a≈ø≈øent to their Propo≈øitions, and renounce his Cau≈øe, and ruine his friends, and betray the Crown,They cannot in ju≈øtice or in gratitude depo≈øe the King. and depo≈øe and degrade him≈øelfe and his Po≈øterity.

Al≈øo whether they may depo≈øe him, after hee hath by ≈øeverall Acts of parliament a≈ø≈øerted our Liberties, and offered to pa≈ø≈øe what≈øoever is de≈øired again≈øt papi≈øts. And after his gracious condi≈øcentions touching the Forts and Ca≈øtles and the Militia,The depriving of the King, a con≈øequent in every Rebellion. for our ≈øecurity; and after his other condi≈øcentions declared in his an≈øwere to the ninteene Propo≈øitions. And after his gracious Me≈ø≈øages from Nottingham and Oxford, both that upon the Treaty there, and the other about a yeere ≈øince, which ≈øee before.

1 Sam. 26.9. How wee mu≈øt judge of their after proceedings with his Maje≈øty.
The true ≈øtate of the que≈øtion on the Parliaments ≈øide, in referrence to the Liberty of the Subject in generall, and more particularly of the Royall Party. But this is an ordinary con≈øequent in every Rebellion, The Rebels not ≈øuffering the king to live or Reigne, which might puni≈øh or take revenge of his Trea≈øon, as is evident in Ed. and Ki. both the ≈øecond. And this al≈øo the Judges delivered for matter of Law, at the arraignement afore≈øaid,

And in this ca≈øe mu≈øt we ground our judgement of their after proceedings with his M ‚Ä¢ je≈øty, on the Sentence of the Lawe, and on the Evidences of Hi≈øtories, and not on their Declarations, alterable at plea≈øure, as them≈øelves averre.

La≈øtly (the promi≈øes con≈øidered) The true ≈øtate of the Que≈øtion on the Parliaments ≈øide, in referrence to the Liberty of the Subject in generall, and more particularly to the Royall party, is cleerely this; Not whether the Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, have power over
our Lawes, Lives, Liberties and e≈øtates, in Ca≈øe of defence, as afore≈øaid; But whether they have power to compell us to ≈øerve with our per≈øons and e≈øtates in the pre≈øent warre again≈øt his Maje≈øty? and in Ca≈øe of refu≈øall, whether they may proceede again≈øt us, and whether each hou≈øe hath power in this Ca≈øe to ≈øeque≈øter and impri≈øon us.

As al≈øo his Maje≈øties taking up Armes for the rea≈øons above mentioned, and requiring us to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in this warre, whether they may que≈øtion and puni≈øh us for ≈øuch a≈ø≈øi≈øtance;The≈øe legall Oathes obliege us rather then our late vowes and covenants. ≈øeeing we are bound by the Oathes of Supremacie and Allegiance, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt ‚Ä¢ nd defend all Juri≈ødictions, Preheminencies, and Authorities belonging to the King, his Heires and Succe≈ø≈øours, or annexed to the Imperiall Crowne.
And for ≈øuch Deede and Service, we are utterly di≈øcharged of any vexation, trouble or lo≈ø≈øe. 11. Hen. 7. cap. 10.

And whereas the Parliament in their an≈øweres hereto grant it to be dutie of allegiance,Ob. to ≈øerve the King in warre for the defence of him and of the Land, but not in warres again≈øt the Land or the Parliament, the Repre≈øentative body thereof.

It may be replied and truely;Sol. That the greater part of the Lords and Commons, and con≈øequently of the people of the Land, taken collectively, and in Parliament joyned with the King before the Tumults; as did the greater part of the people diffu≈øively take part with his Maje≈øty before they called in our brethren of Scotland,Upon „Äà‚óä„Äâ what termes they called in the Scots whom they invited by ≈øeverall Me≈ø≈øages, Declarations, Prote≈øtations, Atte≈øtations, A≈ø≈øeverations and Oathes,
They profe≈ø≈øe declarations alterable at plea≈øure.
See the Scots papers printed at Edinborough June 1646. in te≈øtimony of their un≈øhaken, Re≈øolved and con≈øtant Loyalty to his Maje≈øty and to his Po≈øterity: But now they have Notoriou≈øly and profe≈ø≈øedly revolted from both: and when the Scots-Commis≈øioners urged tho≈øe Declarations and atte≈øtations again≈øt them and their proceedings, they an≈øwered that Returnes ≈øhould not be made again≈øt England, upon their former Declarations, as if they were obligations, whereas they were alterable at plea≈øure.

And now, that by the helpe of our Brethren, they are Conquerors, and ab≈øolute Ma≈øters of all; ≈øee how they fall againe upon their de≈øigne again≈øt his Maje≈øty, and again≈øt Monarchy: and drive it on with all might and main, and by all waies and meanes now, as at the beginning; and what was Trea≈øon before is Rebellion now.

div.head: Their Proceedings after the Warre, the ≈øame as before the Warre.
div.p: They ≈øtickle about the Elections.1. Then they ≈øtickled for ≈øuch men to bee elected into the Hou≈øe of Commons, as were of their opinions and inclinations: and ≈øo they doe now.
Bills again≈øt Bi≈øhops, & for the Militia.2. The Bills again≈øt Bi≈øhops, and for the Militia, were in the fir≈øt place in≈øi≈øted on then: and ≈øo they are now.

3. Seditious and Trayterous pamphlets were publi≈øhed then,Trayterous Pamphlets. as now, by Mr. Lilburne, by Mr. Chaloner and his vindicator, by the authour of the booke called The unhappy game betweene the Scots and Engli≈øh, and by others, profe≈ø≈øed enemies to his Maje≈øty and Monarchy.
